channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Secret military operation led by ex-Green Beret to ouster Venezuela's Maduro fails
item.description: A secret plan to send 300 heavily armed volunteers under the advisement of former Green Beret Jordan Goudreau to overthrow Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro Moros has failed.

item.title: Kim Jong-Un makes his first public appearance for 20 days at a fertiliser plant
item.description: The despot cut the ribbon (pictured) at the opening of a fertiliser factory in Sunchon, state media reported, and released pictures supposedly showing the event.
item.media:credit: KCNA VIA KNS/AFP via Getty Image

item.title: Commuters told to check temperatures before leaving home individual towns cities on lockdown
item.description: Workers could also be forced to take their temperature before they leave home in a bid to stop crowded Tubes and trains becoming death traps across Britain.

item.title: Two VERY different strategies being considered to take Australia out of lockdown
item.description: Australia could use one of two very different strategies to take the country out of lockdown, leading researchers have revealed.

item.title: Many companies will keep in place changes made during coronavirus lockdown, study finds
item.description: Research by the Institute of Directors indicated there will also be a greater focus on digital services when the current lockdown ends. It revealed more are likely to pursue online training for staff.

item.title: China censorship deleted critical coronavirus articles and social media posts written in Morse code
item.description: One deleted article about the situation in Wuhan (pictured) that caused particular outcry was typed out again and re-posted by dozens of social media users in 10 languages to test out censorship levels.

item.title: Film-maker Michael Moore's latest exposé raises host of troubling questions about the eco bandwagon
item.description: It's a pity that the emotional energy generated by the documentary Michael Moore Presents: Planet Of The Humans, can't be used on the national grid, writes TOM LEONARD.

item.title: Britain will begin formal negotiations with the US on a trade deal next week via video conference
item.description: Britain will kickstart formal negotiations with the U.S. on a trade deal next week. International Trade Secretary Liz Truss (pictured) will begin the talks with her American counterpart by video call.

item.title: Buying PPE is 'like Wild West', says care service director who paid £60,000 for non-existent stock
item.description: Care agencies have turned to online suppliers due to a lack of PPE for staff. AMG Nursing and Care Services were scammed when they put in a desperate order for 100,000 masks.

item.title: Costa Coffee will reopen another 29 stores across Britain for deliveries and drive-through orders
item.description: Four branches re-opened in Manchester and Bristol on April 24, a month after the lockdown began - but 12 delivery only and 17 drive-through stores will re-open today in Edinburgh, Glasgow, and Leeds.

item.title: Don't stop attending 'life-saving' vaccination appointments
item.description: NHS England says that routine jabs such as those for MMR (measles, mumps and rubella) are essential in preventing other serious diseases that could place health services under more pressure.

item.title: Cardiff University students return to their halls to find their belongings thrown into bin bags
item.description: When some Cardiff University students returned to their Talybont South halls of residence they found some of their possessions had been thrown into bins during their absence (pictured)

item.title: EDEN CONFIDENTIAL: David Beckham's sister closes concierge business
item.description: RICHARD EDEN: As David Beckham's wife, Victoria, struggles to keep her fashion label going, his sister has been forced to admit defeat with her own business aimed at the rich and famous.

item.title: Lockdown horror as boy, 11, is shot in East London
item.description: A number of suspects had made off prior to the arrival of police at an address in Kerry Drive, Upminster at 9.30pm on Friday. where they found two people - a man and a boy - suffering injuries.

item.title: Why was PC Keith Palmer left so vulnerable? Damning dossier provides disturbing clues
item.description: Armed only with a baton and pepper spray, PC Keith Palmer was stabbed to death by terrorist Khalid Masood on March 22, 2017 in Westminster, London. His wife Michelle is now suing the police.

item.title: Previously-unseen photographs emerge of Iranian Embassy siege 40 years after the hostages were taken
item.description: Members of the SAS, a special regiment of the British Army, begin their assault on the Iranian Embassy in London, 40 years ago (pictured). New, unseen images have emerged of the siege.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are children more at risk than we've been told?
item.description: Ill children have been urgently referred to hospital with 'coronavirus-related syndrome', which has blood inflammation similar to Covid-19. Two-year-old Bertie Brown was not tested for the virus.

item.title: National Trust stops cleaning rivers and may have to pause planting trees
item.description: The charity has called for 'renewal over mere recovery' and urges ministers to prioritise the climate after the pandemic crisis.

item.title: Re-usable PPE that could last for whole coronavirus pandemic could solve NHS shortages
item.description: The re-usable PPE, designed by British scientists and manufacturers, has the potential to replace throwaway items.

item.title: Scrubs actor Sam Lloyd dies at 56 after battling an inoperable brain tumor last year
item.description: Known for playing the downtrodden lawyer Ted Buckland on the show, Lloyd had been battling an inoperable brain tumor last year.

item.title: Hundreds of Germans gather in Berlin to mark May Day despite ban on mass public gatherings
item.description: Police blocked roads around the square in Berlin's Kreuzberg district, traditionally the centre of left-wing May Day protests that had turned violent in the past, to prevent more people from joining.

item.title: Wizz Air becomes first airline to resume overseas flights to Romania, Hungary, Portugal and Spain
item.description: Passengers at Luton Airport, Bedfordshire, socially distanced as they queued to check-in and wore masks. The Mangusher family (right) were travelling to Bulgaria, to visit their family.

item.title: Sir Michael Palin reveals he set fire to his house and was rescued by 86-year-old neighbour
item.description: The Monty Python legend, 76, was recuperating at home after open-heart surgery in September to repair two valves.

item.title: NHS coronavirus tracing app will ask users for personal details despite privacy concerns
item.description: The app has been devised by NHSX, the digital arm of the Health Service. If someone downloads it, Bluetooth technology is likely to track who they come within 6ft of for at least 15 minutes.

item.title: UK holiday letting firms reported to competition regulator by Which? over denying Covid-19 refunds
item.description: Frustrated customers got in touch with the consumer champion saying they were struggling to secure their money back from companies such as Skyes Holiday Cottages and Hoseseasons.

item.title: Coronavirus: Drug trials could end lockdown before a vaccine
item.description: The potential new drugs provide a much quicker route out of the crisis than waiting for a vaccine, a paper published today by experts from Chelsea and Wesminster Hospital claims.

item.title: How cat allergies could soon be prevented by injecting pets
item.description: American company Indoor Biotechnologies have used a gene editing tool to eliminate the production of the protein in cats which causes some people to suffer allergic reactions.

item.title: Gordon Ramsay 'gets warning for flouting lockdown after being spotted miles from Cornwall bolthole'
item.description: Ramsay, 53, has been seen in Rock, Fowey, Port Isaac and Newquay - some distance from his £4million home in Trebetherick. Pictured: The alleged moment Ramsay ran the red light.

item.title: Foo Fighters' charity cover single knocks Colonel Tom Moore off the top of the charts
item.description: A star-studded cover version of the Foo Fighters track Times Like These has knocked Colonel Tom Moore off the top of the UK charts.

item.title: US Military scientists working on germ warfare make COVID-19 test
item.description: DARPA is making a new kind of coronavirus test that looks for an immune response to coronavirus. It may detect the virus much earlier than current diagnostics. DARPA has filed for FDA authorization.

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein had his own OFFICE at Harvard, damning report reveals
item.description: Harvard math professor Martin Nowak was placed on administrative leave on Friday after a new report claimed he gave unprecedented campus access to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Asima Ali-Taha 34 originally from Sudan goes missing in Bristol as police seek man on phone
item.description: Asima Ali-Taha, 34, was last seen in Counterslip, Bristol at around 3pm on April 24.

item.title: Education chiefs call for PPE for all teachers once schools reopen
item.description: Education leaders have demanded that all teachers receive sufficient PPE once schools open and that the government publish 'workable' social distancing rules for schools.

item.title: Border Force officers in France seize £20million worth of cocaine
item.description: The haul, which had a potential street value of around £20 million, was discovered within a number of plywood boxes in a lorry carrying a consignment of car parts.

item.title: Normal People laid bare: Between the sheets of the BBC hit
item.description: Normal People tells the story of Marianne (right) and Connell (left), who fall in love in sixth form, and charts their on-off relationship through university. The series is being hailed as 'perfect'.

item.title: Holidaymakers face six-month wait for refunds as airlines struggle with backlog with £7billion owed
item.description: Millions of travellers are owed money for cancelled flights amid the coronavirus pandemic. EU laws say customers should get refunds in seven days but backlogs mean they are waiting longer.

item.title: AMANDA PLATELL: Britain must not become a nation of snitches on neighbours
item.description: AMANDA PLATELL: We have always been a nation of curtain twitchers. But, who'd have thought nearly 200,000 people would report their neighbours for breaking lockdown rules?

item.title: Kate Middleton spent her ninth wedding anniversary working
item.description: According to the Court Circular the Duchess spent her wedding anniversary in a roundtable dicusssion with charities supporting mothers and pregnant women, from her Anmer Hall home in Norfolk.

item.title: Forget swanky kitchens, a pantry will make your butter and potatoes taste better
item.description: Thinking about it now, the place I was happiest as a child was in my mother's larder. It was that special room where you could cool your bare feet in summer; always dimly lit by a small window.

item.title: 'If I had half Jeeves's brain I'd have a stab at being Prime Minister!'
item.description: You will notice, as you flit through these reminiscences of mine, that from time to time the scene of action is laid in and around the city of New York.

item.title: DR MAX THE MIND DOCTOR: Don't fall victim to furlough Merlot
item.description: If you have found yourself reaching for a soothing glass of wine or three, or a hefty gin and tonic each night during lockdown, then DR MAX THE MIND DOCTOR has some tips for you.

item.title: Millie Mackintosh PIC EXC: Pregnant star and Hugo Taylor leave home
item.description: The sighting came just hours before the couple revealed they had welcomed their first child in a touching statement released to Hello! Magazine

item.title: Canada PM Justin Trudeau bans assault-style weapons after Nova Scotia mass shooting leaves 22 dead
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited numerous mass shootings in the country, including the rampage that killed 22 in Nova Scotia April 18 and 19, while banning more than 1,500 firearm models.

item.title: EDEN CONFIDENTIAL: Michelle Mone reveals how she is getting camera-ready at home in lockdown
item.description: RICHARD EDEN: While most of us are going to seed during lockdown, Ultimo lingerie co-founder Baroness Mone of Mayfair who presents on QVC is determined to keep up appearances.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... The coronavirus 'R' value and Boris Johnson's new baby
item.description: To order a print of this Paul Thomas cartoon or one by Pugh, visit Mailpictures.newsprints.co.uk or call 0191 6030 178.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Matt Hancock accused of test number 'fiddle'
item.description: It has emerged that the Department of Health is counting home tests kits that have been sent out - but not necessarily returned and processed.

item.title: Sunny April weather could mean a bumper apple harvest this autumn, says National Trust
item.description: April's sunny weather could mean a bumper apple harvest this autumn says the National Trust, which cares for more than 200 orchards across England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

item.title: JOHN HUMPHRYS says the coronavirus crisis has been a tragedy but has had many benefits
item.description: JOHN HUMPHRYS: The pandemic has changed our way of life dramatically and we're starting to get the hang of it and even, dare I say it, enjoy it.

item.title: Kuwaiti man denies stabbing Omani student to death outside Harrods 'while trying to steal his watch'
item.description: Kuwaiti national Badir Rahim Alnazi is accused of attacking Omani student Mohamed Abdullah Al Araimi (pictured) near the luxury department store in Knightsbridge last December.

item.title: Window washers fly through the air as winds of 47mph hit their platform during sudden Florida storm
item.description: The incident, which was caught on video by people standing on a nearby balcony, took place on Thursday afternoon, at the Ritz-Carlton Residences in Sunny Isles Beach, Florida.

item.title: Princess Charlotte, five today, drops off homemade pasta to vulnerable Norfolk residents
item.description: To mark her birthday, Kensington Palace has released new pictures of Charlotte (pictured) as she helped her parents deliver home-made pasta to vulnerable Norfolk residents in isolation.

item.title: Robert Hardman says Sir Winston Churchill would be proud of £5million Mail Force donations
item.description: ROBERT HARDMAN: I have no doubt Sir Winston Churchill (pictured outside Downing Street in April 1945) would be equally moved by the magnificent response to the call to arms by Mail Force.

item.title: Reddit kills chat feature after complaints from moderators that it made forums prone to abuse
item.description: Reddit's moderators who oversee the site's many subreddits say the 'Start Chatting' feature made the process of monitoring content and behavior more opaque and prone to abuse.

item.title: Lockdown lust files: Three quarters of Britons say social isolation benefited their relationships
item.description: An 'isolationship' survey asked 1,600 women how lockdown changed their relationships and lives. For Gemma Birkbeck, 32, lockdown has made her relationship with Kris Brook, 34, more intimate.

item.title: Royal Horticultural Society puts flower show online with a public competition
item.description: Amateur gardeners are being asked to submit snaps of their gardens online in an effort to find the best home-grown garden during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: 'I can't wait to move!': Majority of buyers vow to crack on with moves
item.description: Getting the deal done looks set to become a tag-line for the property market as transactions remain on hold and more people look to move outside of big cities like London and Birmingham.

item.title: Donald Trump ends 32-day lockdown by flying to Camp David with officials including Hope Hicks
item.description: The president took with him a group of senior officials including Hope Hicks, who was seen for the first time since she returned to the White House in March, and his son-in-law Jared Kushner.

item.title: New book reveals the dramas inside the walls of Kensington Palace
item.description: Very little escapes the notice of servants at Kensington Palace, writes TOM QUINN, the author of Kensington Palace: An Intimate Memoir from Queen Mary to Meghan Markle.

item.title: How Alan Titchmarsh felt 'teary' after garden centre owner gives away £500,000 worth of plants
item.description: TV gardener Alan Titchmarsh thought 'it was the nicest thing' when Kirton Farm Nurseries, of Winchester, started handing out free flowers to households in Hampshire rather than bin them.

item.title: Gardeners' World enjoys its highest viewing figures in a decade because of lockdown
item.description: The BBC2 show, which saw Monty Don self-filming footage from his garden, drew an audience of 2.7million on April 24 as the programme was made for the first time by a socially-distanced crew.

item.title: Coronavirus US: Death toll hits 63,849 with 2,239 new fatalities
item.description: The number of deaths in the United States from coronavirus is now well over 63,000 - a harrowing increase from just two months ago when only two fatalities had been reported.

item.title: Priti Patel admits 7% rise in knife crime is 'appalling' and says Sadiq Khan 'should be doing more'
item.description: Home Secretary Priti Patel said an overall fall in recorded crime could not mask the misery caused by a sharp rise in knife offences in England and Wales, which are at a record high.

item.title: Playboy tycoon James Stunt will be charged with money laundering and forgery
item.description: Former gold bullion dealer James Stunt, 38, who was once married to Formula One heiress Petra Ecclestone, will be summonsed to appear in court in July.

item.title: Welsh government pays 64,000 care workers £500 bonus as thank-you for working during Covid crisis
item.description: First Minister Mark Drakeford told the Welsh Government's briefing on Friday: 'This payment is designed to provide some further recognition of the value we attach to everything they are doing.'

item.title: Coronavirus Sweden: Daily deaths fall but doubts over strategy
item.description: Sweden's latest figures today showed 428 new cases in the last 24 hours, down from 790 yesterday, taking the total from 21,092 to 21,520 (the daily cases are shown on this graph).

item.title: Brazilians start defying isolation, egged on by Bolsonaro
item.description: Support for isolation is dimming among Brazilians who agree with President Jair Bolsonaro's view that the coronavirus pandemic has been exaggerated as Brazil surpassed China in COVID-19 deaths.

item.title: Easy one-pan bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich hack goes viral
item.description: TikTok users are going wild after a home cook from New Jersey shared a very clever way to make a bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich - all in one pan in just a few minutes.

item.title: Jeff Bezos called by Congress as Amazon faces perjury questions
item.description: The Amazon founder has been told he should appear in front of the House Judiciary Committee after his general counsel denied using third-party data under oath.

item.title: Why do some people get two coronavirus tests?
item.description: Dr Paul Hunter, a medicine lecturer at the University of East Anglia, said it was 'valid' for people to be tested more than once and that tests are not perfect so may have to be repeated.

item.title: Remarkable black and white images capture the stores along historic Route 66 during the 1950s
item.description: A cache of stunning images of historic Route 66 during the 1950s were unearthed after the death of Charles Custer, a Chicago resident who had taken them on early road trips with his wife.

item.title: Alex Salmond 'helps British arm of Russia Today increase turnover by £15million'
item.description: The former Scottish First Minister was widely criticised for taking a job with Vladimir Putin's 'propaganda' channel, formerly known as Russia Today, on its English-language service.

item.title: VE Day flypast will go over Care for Veterans home, NHS hospital and Colonel Tom Moore's house
item.description: Our Spitfire Mk IX, donated by the Goodwood-based Boultbee Spitfire Academy, will take to the skies in tribute to the British veterans.

item.title: Cancer care and baby death warnings as NHS battles to restart treatment delayed by coronavirus
item.description: After Boris Johnson claimed the UK has 'passed the peak' of covid-19, politicians face a battle to reopen hospitals and specialist services to those whose operations and care were put on hold.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Interactive map shows fatalities by postcode
item.description: The map, created by the Office for National Statistics, shows deprived regions in England and Wales are suffering 55 deaths per 100,000 people, compared to 25 deaths in affluent areas.

item.title: BEL MOONEY: Is my son unfaithful because of his dad's cheating?
item.description: This week Bel advises a reader who is afraid her son's extra-marital affair is a result of his own father's cheating.

item.title: The most divine British Isles! Magnificent coastal havens from Lundy to Newquay and St Kilda
item.description: Whether it's the setting of an Agatha Christie murder mystery, a puffin paradise or the former home of a crazed king, Britain is littered with tiny isles on which you can stay in seclusion.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 77% support lockdown extension next week
item.description: Some 46 per cent of those surveyed said they would 'strongly support' the decision to extend lockdown, according to a new YouGov poll of 3152 adults.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 27,510 with 739 fatalities
item.description: Officials recorded another 6,000 cases, with 177,000 Britons having now been infected since the crisis began in February - but a lack of testing means potentially millions of cases were missed.

item.title: You might need a splash of Mauritius magic after we get through all this!
item.description: Mark Twain once quoted a Mauritius local as saying that 'heaven was copied after Mauritius' after he visited in 1896. The Daily Mail's Kate Johnson headed to the island to see if it still rings true.

item.title: Is this the future of travel? From blood tests during check-in to plastic booths around plane seats
item.description: The only certainty is that the future of travel is uncertain. We'll all have to get used to a whole new travel landscape once coronavirus restrictions are lifted. So what will it look like?

item.title: Ireland eases two lockdown restrictions
item.description: Ireland's premier Leo Varadkar has announced an extension of the country's coronavirus restrictions to May 18 with two exceptions.

item.title: JONATHAN MAYO imagines 'the new normal' one year after Britain emerges from lockdown
item.description: Drawing on scientific predictions and the experiences of other countries to Britain emerging from isolation, JONATHAN MAYO imagines the 'new normal'.

item.title: U.S. says Maduro regime is linked to $165million worth of cocaine seized off Spain's coast
item.description: Spain's military seized a vessel April 25 that crossed the Atlantic Ocean with 4.4 tons of cocaine that were loaded off the coast of Venezuela earlier in the month.

item.title: Tom Watson went on lobbying mission with former UK Music boss two years before becoming chairman
item.description: The row over Tom Watson's appointment to a top music industry job intensified after it emerged he went on a lobbying mission with the former head of the organisation he now chairs.

item.title: Elon Musk Twitter rant sends Tesla shares tumbling by 11%
item.description: 'Tesla stock price is too high imo,' Elon Musk tweeted at around 11:11am Eastern Time on Friday. Right after he posted this tweet, Tesla shares began a precipitous nosedive.

item.title: Chinese manufacturers begin making 'anti-virus' cars designed to minimize coronavirus transmission
item.description: Some Chinese auto manufacturers have begun offering new design features they promise will help limit the transmission of bacteria and viruses in their vehicles, including Sars-CoV-2.

item.title: Mail Force PPE donations reach £5million as facemasks land at UK hospices
item.description: Staff at the Mountbatten Hampshire centre said they were 'overwhelmed' by last night's delivery of thousands of life-saving masks and coveralls.

item.title: Britain's Gran Talent: Singer, 96, with Alzheimer's will become BGT's oldest ever contestant
item.description: Nora Barton, 96, who has Alzheimer's will tonight fulfil her dream of singing at the London Palladium - becoming the oldest ever contestant on Britain's Got Talent to boot - to prove life isn't for being put on hold.

item.title: Funds to defend your savings from the market rout
item.description: In future, more people may want to preserve their money, rather than maximise returns. Fund managers like Jonathan Ruffer who are committed to safeguarding could become power players.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Why were life sciences firms left out of the loop?
item.description: What Britain's fight against coronavirus has shown is the monolithic approach of Public Health England at the outset of the crisis was a terrible error, which frustrated the medical research community.

item.title: Heartbreaking photographs reveal doctors and nurses working a 12-hour night shift
item.description: Photographer Christopher Bobyn of Nine, BBC News Scotland was granted exclusive access to the NHS ICU at Hairmyres hospital, in East Kilbride Scotland over a period of 12 hours.
item.media:credit: Christopher Bobyn - Photos courtesy of the Nine, BBC Scotland

item.title: Government officials spray a Spanish beach with BLEACH to protect locals from coronavirus
item.description: Government officials in a small coastal town in Spain sprayed a beach with a diluted bleach solution in the hopes of protecting residents from COVID-19 as they emerge from lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus Germany: Infection rate rises as lockdown eased
item.description: Germany has eased some lockdown measures but is seeing a rise in the number of Covid-19 cases, with infections rising for the fifth day in a row. Pictured: Graph of Covid-19 cases in Germany.

item.title: Coronavirus: Man tests positive five weeks after symptoms end
item.description: Charles Pignal, 42, of Singapore, tested positive for coronavirus on March 4 and kept testing positive for the next 40 days even though his symptoms cleared in less than a week.

item.title: Trump claims Joe Biden could face MORE women 'coming out'
item.description: President Donald Trump on Friday predicted more accusers would come out against Joe Biden and said he was 'sticking up' for the former vice president.

item.title: Hope for couples trying for a baby as fertility services are allowed to reopen
item.description: The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) said fertility clinics across the UK can apply to reopen from May 11 if they ensure the safety and protection of staff and patients.

item.title: Over 100 prison staff form guard of honour for first female officer, 33, to die of coronavirus
item.description: Rachael Yates, 33, had 'loved' her work at HMP Usk in Monmouthshire, Wales. She had continued working there during the coronavirus pandemic. Her mother said she had lacked essential PPE.

item.title: Coronavirus: How UK death toll compares with rest of world
item.description: Data from a project led by University of Oxford researchers shows that Britain's rate of 394 deaths per million is the fourth worst in world behind Italy, Spain and Belgium.

item.title: New antibiotic developed to fight superbugs could be used to treat pneumonia in COVID-19 patients
item.description: Researchers have shown that the drug can successfully combat potentially fatal lung infections in both mice, as well as human cells grown in the laboratory.

item.title: Police watchdog launches inquiry after officer 'kicks and hits a 15-year-old drugs suspect'
item.description: The Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC) said CCTV footage of the incident in Newtown, Birmingham, had been shared on social media and caused significant public concern.

item.title: Judges and magistrates must consider Covid-crisis gripping prisons, Lord Burnett says
item.description: The Lord Chief Justice Lord Burnett believes that those in charge of passing sentences should take into account that the impact of a custodial stint may now be greater on an offender due to the pandemic.

item.title: Man, 41, is charged with the murder of widower, 88, who was found dead at his quiet Surrey home
item.description: Darren McClean of Coneybury, Bletchingley, has been charged with murder today after the body of 88-year-old Dennis Kellond (pictured) was discovered in his Surrey bungalow on Monday.

item.title: Court orders Volkswagen to pay £3million after ruling it installed unlawful 'defeat devices' in cars
item.description: Volkswagen was refused permission to appeal against a damning High Court ruling saying it installed unlawful 'defeat devices' in thousands of its diesel cars. Around 90,000 motorists took legal action.
item.media:description: VW will be pursuing an appeal directly to the Court of Appeal (Gareth Fuller/PA)

item.title: Mesmerising images by Amos Chapple of Prague's fascinating rooftop statues and sculptures
item.description: Top photographer Amos Chapple has taken a set of fascinating photographs of Prague's rooftop statues and sculptures, from the beautiful to the bizarre and from the elegant to the grotesque.

item.title: Real call of nature: Homeowners report frogs are emerging through sinks and toilets
item.description: Three separate Chesterfield addresses have reported finding frogs (pictured) coming out of of their sinks, toilets and drains, fearing that the creatures have 'infiltrated their water systems'.

item.title: Why ARE we so exhausted during lockdown?
item.description: Angela Cox, a behavioural change life coach, told FEMAIL that what many people in the UK and beyond are feeling right now is the impact of the Kubler Ross Change Curve.

item.title: Coronavirus: Death rate 250% higher for black and Asian Britons
item.description: The respected think-tank found the death rate among Black African Britons was three times that of the white British population. Fatalities among Pakistanis were 2.7 times higher.

item.title: Amazon sacks delivery driver after he's caught on CCTV urinating on customer's garden fence
item.description: The disgusting scene was caught on Thursday by Duncan Spoor from Telford, West Midlands who uploaded the footage from his home CCTV. Stills from the video show a man wearing a hi-vis vest.

item.title: McDonald's worker served burglar who was wearing the cap and watch he had just stolen from him
item.description: Burglar Ross Renforth (pictured) broke into Jake White's home in Alnwick, Northumberland and stole an Adidas cap and Swatch watch he then wore to the McDonald's at which Mr White was working.

item.title: Hong Kong airport trials a disinfection booth that 'can remotely kill viruses in 40 SECONDS
item.description: Hong Kong International Airport is the first place in the world to use the CLeanTech sanitation pods and they are currently being utilised by key workers such as public health staff.

item.title: Rod Stewart returns to Essex home after isolating in Florida as he's seen clapping for carers
item.description: Rod Stewart was seen clapping for the carers with his family on Thursday, following his return to his Essex home after isolating in Florida.

item.title: Britain will bask in 68F again next week after suffering week of downpours, thunderstorms and hail
item.description: Brits will experience a mixed few days of weather this weekend, before the mercury will rise early next week, with sunny spells back on the horizon.

item.title: Harry Dunn's mother is hopeful for personal response from Donald Trump after review request
item.description: Harry Dunn (pictured) was killed in August 2019 when a car collided head-on with his motorcycle outside an RAF base. The car was allegedly being driven by U.S. citizen Anne Sacoolas.

item.title: Police investigating disappearance of woman, 45, last January charge man, 47, with murder
item.description: Susan Waring, 45, (pictured) went missing from Lancashire in January last year. Alan Edwards, 45, was re-arrested on Wednesday and has been charged with her murder.

item.title: Russia's coronavirus crisis continues to worsen with a record 7,922 cases
item.description: Russia's coronavirus crisis continues to worsen with a record 7,922 cases recorded the day after Prime Minister Mikhail Mishtushin (left, inset) tested positive for the disease.

item.title: Councils in 'catastrophe': Town where HALF of workers face being furloughed pleads for PM's help
item.description: More than 50 per cent of jobs in Crawley (pictured on Friday) are at risk of being lost or furloughed, according to a recent report.

item.title: Imported by Brazil's vacationing rich, coronavirus is now devastating the country's poor
item.description: Public health data for the cities of Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro and Fortaleza show a shift in recent weeks from the wealthy boroughs that seeded the coronavirus outbreak to the gritty urban outskirts.

item.title: British Airways owner IAG secures £900m loan from Spanish government
item.description: International Airlines Group, who own British Airways, have so far refused to approach the UK government to seek a loan for BA who are placed 12,000 jobs at risk.

item.title: Domesday Book-era water mills crank back to life in meeting demand for flour during Covid crisis
item.description: Charlecote Mill, Stratford-upon-Avon, was facing closure, it's now working flat out. Sturminster Newton Mill, Dorset has supplied hundreds of bags of flour to meet domestic bakers' demands.

item.title: Husband of woman, 36, who died from Covid-19 after told she 'wasn't priority' can't pay for funeral
item.description: Fabian Williams, 49, from Camberwell, south London, described how Kayla, 36, was slumped on the sofa a day after she was given paracetamol by paramedics. He cannot afford her funeral.

item.title: Warning over 'drastic' changes to GP appointments with over half of consultations to move online
item.description: Chairman of the Royal College of GPs Professor Martin Marshall warned MPs that as many as 50 per cent of GP appointments could be moved online even after the coronavirus pandemic.
item.media:description: Around half of GP consultations could move online following the coronavirus pandemic, a doctors´ leader has said (Anthony Devlin/PA)

item.title: Heart-stopping moment armed police Taser suspect after high speed chase
item.description: Officers in the Trojan Proactive Unit recognised a car with links to criminal activity and set off in pursuit of the driver in Barnet on April 14, with a high speed chase unfolding in broad daylight.

item.title: How to give your Zoom photo a touch of the exotic: Holiday companies make beautiful photos available
item.description: Google Trends data has revealed the most popular destinations for Zoom background pictures, and it's the Caribbean that's in the No1 spot, with searches for locations there up 9,900%.

item.title: India extends lockdown for two weeks, with some easing
item.description: India's lockdown imposed near the end of March has caused misery for millions of workers in India's vast informal sector and dealt a major blow to Asia's third-biggest economy. It has been extended to May 28.

item.title: Russia says 'faster' robots will overtake soldiers on the battlefield in the near future
item.description: Russian researcher Vitaly Davydov has said robots will overtake their human brothers on the battlefield because they will be faster and are more accurate in target selection.

item.title: London at the mercy of militant unions who have Sadiq Khan over a barrel
item.description: Sadiq Khan is at the mercy of militant unions which are demanding a new deal for workers amid warnings London's transport network will be 'rapidly overwhelmed' once the lockdown eases.

item.title: Spectacular pictures reveal a centuries-old royal family golden seal
item.description: Amazing images showed a centuries-old royal family golden seal weighing over 17 pounds unearthed by Chinese archaeologists studying the remnants of a Ming dynasty battlefield on Tuesday.

item.title: Half of rice sold in the UK breaches limits on arsenic for children
item.description: A total of 28 out of 55 varieties included in a study conducted by the University of Sheffield breached the 0.1 mg kg−1 limit laid out by the EU, to which the UK adheres.

item.title: Coronavirus Denmark: Infection rate rose when schools re-opened
item.description: Analysis by Denmark's infectious diseases agency the State Serum Institute (SSI) found the so-called reproduction rate, known as 'R', rose since schools opened on April 15 as the lockdown was eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: Hydroxychloroquine may trigger heart arrhythmia
item.description: More than 90% of COVID-19 patients treated with hydroxychloroquine in studies in France and Boston had longer than normal pauses in their heart beats - a sign of dangerous arrhythmias.

item.title: Coronavirus may increase risk of brain blood vessel blockages
item.description: The small study focused on six patients with confirmed COVID-19 and that had suffered a stroke caused by the sudden loss of blood circulation to the brain.

item.title: Millionaire could face jail for 'refusing to tear down' illegal 10,000 sq ft 'man cave'
item.description: Graham Wildin, 68, installed the 10,000sq ft 'man cave' complex at the back of his home in Cinderford, Glos in 2014, but did not have the required planning permission.

item.title: Christian fostering agency takes Ofsted to the High Court over 'discrimination' claims
item.description: Cornerstone (North East) Adoption and Fostering Service, which operates in the North East of England, is taking watchdog Ofsted to court claiming it is being forced to abandon its religious ethos.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Local tips reopen where councils have PPE
item.description: Some councils said they won't open sites until safety measures put in place. New analysis revealed fly-tipping has increased by 300 per cent during the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: NHS launches probe after senior official 'set up his own online business privately selling PPE'
item.description: David Singleton, 42, a senior NHS official in London - who has reportedly been working at the Nightingale hospital - launched the business two weeks ago to trade in visors, masks and gowns.

item.title: Father-of-two tells of his shock to discover the 'world's biggest chip' measuring seven inches long
item.description: Oliver Dale was making a tea of chicken, chips and salad for his family at their York home when he found the whopping crinkle cut inside a bag of McCain oven chips from Asda, measuring seven inches.

item.title: Furious customers slam Virgin Media and Sky as hundreds across country face broadband issues
item.description: Hundreds of Virgin Media and Sky broadband customers are without internet this afternoon with both companies suffering issues, according to Down Detector.

item.title: Pregnant care worker given a ticket for parking outside her home 20 minutes after a long night shift
item.description: Samantha Blake was left with no choice but to leave her car on double yellow lines as everywhere else near her home in Plymouth was full. She left a note on her car to explain to passing parking wardens.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: London supermorgue triples size to hold 3,000
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: The site in Epping Forest was originally designed to cope with 1,000 bodies but has now been expanded to deal with 3,000 people as the nation continues its battle against Covid-19.

item.title: Global smartphone sales show the 'biggest decline ever'
item.description: Global smartphone shipments have fallen by 16.8 percent due to worldwide lockdowns to stop the spread of coronavirus, reports analyst firm Omdia.

item.title: Coronavirus: Judge rules mother was 'wrong' to take son to Greek island of Paros to flee outbreak
item.description: The mother made the decision to board a flight from London to the Greek island of Paros on March 20 with her 11-year-old son, three days before Boris Johnson began a lockdown in the UK.

item.title: Journalist and author John Bryant who was pivotal to London marathon's success dies aged 76
item.description: Mr Bryant, pictured, passed away peacefully at his home in Surrey on Thursday following a long battle with illness.

item.title: Husband builds his hairdresser wife's 'dream' home salon in their back garden for £6,000
item.description: Mobile hairstylist Stephanie Sutherland, 34, had always dreamed of a fully functional salon at her Edinburgh home but joiner husband Wayne, 35, never had the time due to work commitments.

item.title: Stanley Johnson says Meghan was 'in driving seat' for her and Harry's California move
item.description: Prince Harry and his former actress wife, Meghan, fled the UK earlier this year and are searching for a home in Los Angeles. Stanley Johnson took a swipe in the Saga Magazine.

item.title: Whistleblower claims elderly Covid-19 patients are being 'sent to die' in care homes
item.description: The source, whose work means they have close connections with care homes in the UK, told FEMAIL people are being discharged from hospital before their coronavirus test results are known.

item.title: Mother whose son, 24, was stabbed to death just days after his father died tells of her pain
item.description: EXCLUSIVE: Marian Gomoh, 53, has revealed her anguish over losing her son David, 24, who was fatally wounded in Canning Town, London, days after his father, Ken, died from coronavirus.

item.title: Britain's R number plummeted when the lockdown was introduced
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson last night put the reproduction rate of the coronavirus at the heart of Britain's crisis and said he would not do anything which risks triggering another outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: Low Vitamin D could mean higher risk of death
item.description: Scientists from the University of East Anglia write in their study: 'We believe, that we can advise Vitamin D supplementation to protect against SARS-CoV2 infection.'

item.title: Honeybees are being wiped out by disease that causes chronic paralysis
item.description: Honey bees in the UK are increasingly suffering at the hands of a deadly viral disease called chronic bee paralysis virus, according to a new study from Newcastle University.

item.title: Meghan Markle: Multiple claims dismissed in Mail on Sunday case
item.description: The Duchess of Sussex, 38, is suing Associated Newspapers over an article which reproduced parts of a handwritten note she sent to Mr Markle, 75, in August 2018.

item.title: Moment policewoman breaks down in tears after thug spits BLOOD in her eye
item.description: Temisan Oritsejafor, 41, launched the sickening attack on PC Annie Napier who was detaining him after he assaulted his neighbour in in Wyken, Coventry.

item.title: The man who appears on the VE Day commemorative stamps was a barrow boy
item.description: George Sumpter was one of seven children born in the Soho slums of Edwardian London in 1906, and worked as a barrow boy in Covent Garden market.

item.title: Downing Street: 'questions that need to be answered' over coronavirus origin
item.description: Downing Street said today there are 'questions that need to be answered' about the origin of coronavirus after Donald Trump claimed it may have originated in a Chinese laboratory.

item.title: Couple ordered to cut 80ft trees in their garden after neighbouring flat owners used high-hedge laws
item.description: Ferdinando and Angelina Franchitti claim chopping down their 80ft conifer trees will ruin the privacy of their detached home in Bothwell, Lanarkshire, following complaints from three neighbouring flats.

item.title: Coronavirus: Ryanair warns up to 3,000 jobs will be cut
item.description: Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary has today cut up to 3,000 jobs but vowed to refund 25 million out-of-pocket customers - as Heathrow reports losses of £315 million.

item.title: Wedding guests who witnessed first-hand OBJECTIONS reveal their stories
item.description: Writing on anonymous sharing app Whisper, wedding guests from around the globe have recalled the times they have witnessed someone objecting on the big day.

item.title: Speeding offences in London were up 650% last week
item.description: Some 2,020 speeding offences were enforced across London last week - an eight-fold increase compared to the same seven days in 2019.

item.title: 'PuffPacket' device that attaches to e-cigarettes created to track vaping habits
item.description: Experts from Cornell Tech created an 'unobtrusive' monitor that can track when people vape, how deeply they inhale and how much nicotine they consume.

item.title: Police hunt thieves after collection of rare antique cameras worth £30,000 is stolen from lock up
item.description: Police were called to a storage facility in Waltham Forest on the morning of 20 April by a member of staff, who said that one of the storage units had been broken into. The victim was contacted.

item.title: McDonald's will reopen 15 restaurants for delivery
item.description: The fast food giant has revealed it will reopen 15 restaurants for delivery only, with the locations of these restaurants across the UK being announced next week.

item.title: Boy, 7, asks his father 'who's next' after losing his mother and grandmother
item.description: Speaking to Sky News, Chris Cadby from Cardiff broke down as he revealed the moment his son asked 'who was next' after the youngster lost his mother and grandmother in just four days.

item.title: Woman left with 'bare' eyes after botched extensions hails wonder serum for restoring lashes
item.description: Nadia Hallett, 23, from Hertfordshire, told FEMAIL she was devastated when the individual lash extensions she'd got for her 21st birthday ripped away her natural hairs when she removed them.

item.title: Savvy mum reveals how to make your food shopping last under lockdown
item.description: Laura Swain, 28, from Weston-Super-Mare, has revealed how to make a £4 chicken last for three different meals - including a roast chicken dinner, chicken pasta bake and chicken noodle soup.

item.title: Seven arrested in murder probe after man, 34, dies following assault
item.description: Northumbria Police were called to Croften Street, in Blyth, Northumberland at 1.15pm on Wednesday, where they found a 34-year-old man who had been assaulted.

item.title: Sudan criminalises female genital mutilation
item.description: Sudan has criminalised female genital mutilation (FGM), making it punishable by three years in jail, a move campaigners said ushered in a 'new era' for women's rights in the African nation.

item.title: Backlash over delay in coronavirus face masks advice
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon has already urged Scots to don home-made masks - but not medical-grade ones - in shops and on public transport.

item.title: Women share photos from home for virtual Punchestown Festival Ladies Day
item.description: Glamorous women have been taking part in a virtual fashion competition to mark what would have been the Punchestown Festival Ladies Day.

item.title: Woman transforms her bathroom for less than £400 after her professional refit was cancelled
item.description: Blogger Hayley Rubery, 29, from Essex, was scheduled to have a complete refit of her bathroom, but did the job herself using leftover paint, vinyl flooring from eBay and old wood.

item.title: Coronavirus crisis grips TV
item.description: A host of measures are being put in place by TV chiefs to help keep things run as normal once the pandemic is over

item.title: Photos capture a nurse being given a pep talk after a corona patient suffers a heart attack
item.description: It was one of two rapid responses Capri Reese, a nurse for 12 years, had to deal with at Roseland Community Hospital, Chicago, in one 12-hour shift.

item.title: Son of 'Lady In The Lake' killer loses his appeal against his father's conviction for murdering wife
item.description: Gordon Park was jailed for life in 2005 after he battered estranged partner Carol to death with an ice pick in 1976 and dumped her body in Coniston Water in the Lake District.

item.title: Mum spends a year documenting her toddler son's hilarious tantrums
item.description: Rachael Saunders, 34, who lives on the Isle of Barra in the Outer Hebrides, has taken dozens of snaps capturing the illogical triggers which cause two-year-old Fraser to have a meltdown.

item.title: Teenager, 18, gang-raped by seven people after she was abducted as she walked home in India
item.description: A gang of seven, including three minors, threw a woman's brother down a well before launching a sex attack that lasted from 8.30pm until 2am yesterday in the village in Madhya Pradesh, India.
item.media:credit: The India Today Group via Getty

item.title: Mummy of a teenage girl dripping in expensive jewellery discovered
item.description: Spanish archaeologists found the remains of the girl during a dig near the city of Luxor in Egypt and say she would have been 15 or 16 when she died.
item.media:credit: Facebook/ Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities

item.title: Hilarious interior design fails will left you wondering how people could think it was a good idea
item.description: Hilarious US-based Instagram account Terrible Real Estate Agents showcases the worst of the worst interior design found by those trying to sell houses, including bizarre decorations.

item.title: Unlucky zebra's limb sticks out of crocodile's mouth after getting torn to pieces
item.description: A photographer caught the moment the crocodile raised its powerful jaws from the water, with the unfortunate zebra's leg still hanging from its teeth at the Masai Mara National Park in Kenya.

item.title: CCTV shows British man pick up Thai prostitute 'before having drug-fuelled sex then killing her
item.description: Police took Neil Henry Elliott, 46, from Northern Ireland on a parade in handcuffs today, to show them the spot where he collected the woman and drove her away on his motorbike.

item.title: Penguins are given a chance to explore Singapore zoo after lack of human contact left them bored
item.description: Penguins at Singapore zoo are making the most of the country's partial virus lockdown, being given free run of the empty complex and revelling in the chance to do some exploring.

item.title: Boris Johnson calls Captain Tom a 'point of light in all our lives'
item.description: The Prime Minister has called Colonel Tom Moore a 'point of light in our lives' as he wished him a happy birthday and thanked him for helping to pull the nation together through the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Baffling brainteaser challenges you to spot the crayon hidden in the floral wallpaper
item.description: British company Plumbs, who specalise in reupholestry, have created a baffling new brainteaser. Players are asked to spot the crayon hidden among the flowers.

item.title: Army life was the perfect fit for Prince Harry, says Richard Kay
item.description: RICHARD KAY: Yesterday it was reported that Prince Harry (pictured at Westminster Abbey) misses the Army, the camaraderie that comes with a life in uniform and the bonds of war.

item.title: Hairstylist reveals gross build-up caused by silicones and parabens
item.description: Sydney Augusta, from Seattle, Washington, shared the video on TikTok, and in it she is seen using hairdresser scissors to scrape a layer of build-up from a section of her hair.

item.title: Prince Harry 'tells friends he misses the army and cannot believe how his life has panned out'
item.description: The Duke of Sussex told friends he 'cannot believe' how his life has been 'turned upside down' in recent months and believes he would have been better protected if he was still in the Army.
